title: The strategic framework behind a $1.7 billion start-up | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: Founders are very good at just going
straight to execution. But sometimes we
got to think through our ideas to make
sure we end up in the right place. It's
almost like a boat leaving a harbor.
Like you want to make sure you end up in
the right place instead of randomly in
the middle of the ocean. Dr. Iman Abu
Zed's first startup fizzled out and left
her stuck in the middle of that ocean.
But the lessons she learned led her to
an undeniable north star in moving
forward. That north star, listening to
the pain points of her customers. He
spoke with nurses and and really, you
know, heard the urgency in their voice.
It was almost like an emotional
experience for them in terms of just the
problems that they're tackling. Iman saw
an opportunity to disrupt the way nurses
get hired that would benefit everyone
involved. That's why she co-founded
Incredible Health, a marketplace for
health care professionals.
Incredible Health now boasts more than 1
million healthcare workers on the
platform and has reached a valuation of
nearly
$1.7 billion.
This is Masters of Scale.
This week on the show, we'll hear how
Iman Abu Zed's strategic approach to
scale fueled the massive growth of
Incredible Health. But first, we wanted
to hear how she ended up getting bitten
by the entrepreneurship bug after
graduating from medical school. Eman,
welcome to Masters of Scale. Thank you
so much for having me. We're thrilled to
have you. Like so many of the founders
and leaders who have scaled uh companies
in extraordinary ways. Um you're an
immigrant. You didn't grow up here. Um
tell us a little bit about where you
grew up. Sure. So, I'm originally from
Sudan. Uh, that's where my parents are
from. I, uh, lived in Saudi Arabia, in
the Emirates, in the UK. I immigrated to
the US when I was 24 years old. Uh, and
I, you know, worked in management
consulting in New York City and then
moved to and then moved to Philadelphia
to do my MBA at Wharton and then moved
to the San Francisco Bay area. And when
you when you came here, you came here to
do management consulting. That was your
first role here. Is that right? Uh, it
was the first role. Yes. The paths out
of management consulting are are are
many. There there are varied paths. Um
going down an entrepreneurial path is
not what a lot of management consultants
do. Um it's taking on the risk yourself.
It's uh having to give yourself the
advice that you might be giving to
others as a consultant. What inspired
you to become an entrepreneur? Yeah, so
I uh actually went I went to medical
school in London. So I'm an MD by
background. Um and you know if we just
go back to even that time period uh I
was always interested in having a big
impact right uh don't get me wrong like
working as a doctor is a wonderful
career and I recommend it to everyone um
however I I really wanted to find a way
to make an impact on a much larger scale
so after medical school moved to New
York in management consulting that the
benefit of that profession is that it
just a I grew grew a lot of skills and b
just exposed me more to business um And
then certainly the MBA at Wharton helped
me do that even further. But for
entrepreneurship, I I genuinely believe
I think entrepreneurship is one of the
it's like the epitome of what you can do
with a your career in business. Like
it's I think it's amazing. It's like
imagine like a small group of people can
have transform an entire industry. Like
it's it's magic. It's like the coolest
thing. What led you to move out to the
Bay and and and and how did you end up
starting on an on an entrepreneurial
journey? I have a belief that the the
San Francisco Bay area is still the
world's capital of technology. Um if if
if you want to start a a company in
especially a software company, it it
still is the best place. Um and that's
for so many reasons, right? Um you know,
the capital, the talent, the the ideas,
you know, that the network like it's
it's just a really amazing place to
start a company. So I knew I was, you
know, finishing business school in 2013,
like there was only one plan. moved to
the Bay Area. Um, and uh, you know, I
joined as an early sta early uh, excuse
me, I joined as a product manager at an
early stage uh, healthcare technology
company and that's really where I got
exposed to software engineers and data
scientists and designers and and got to
learn what it takes to actually build
products uh, that users love and how to
grow them as well. And so after doing
that for a couple of years uh, left with
a star software engineer that I was
working with Rome Portlock who is a
total whiz went to MIT. He's a fantastic
engineer as well. Uh and we left to to
co-ound uh a company. That's not the
company you're now you now have
co-founded in New Running. What what was
that company? Yeah. So we actually
started working on another idea uh which
for and we worked on it for about a year
which didn't actually work you know it
was actually a it was actually a app for
um um that helped small and medium
healthcare businesses like
chiropractors, physical therapists, you
know so on uh retain their clients. So
it helped them, you know, engage with
them between sessions and so on. And so
it it was live. There was revenue coming
in, but we were really struggling with
growing it. And so we made the decision
after gosh, a year of working on it to
pivot to a different idea. And so just
just take us back if you would. You and
you and Rome are at a fairly early stage
company. How does it come to be that you
leave and start a company together? What
what what actually catalyzed that
decision to do that with each other? I'm
a big fan of thinking through what is
your goal in 5 to 10 years and then work
backwards from there. So I knew at age
you know in my 20s like hey I I know I
want to start a company so what's the
path to get there you know one path is
get to the Bay Area another path is
start you know you don't know you don't
have enough skills so like become a
product manager first you know so all of
that that was like the ultimate goal at
the end of the day and then Rome um Rome
is our you know he's my co-founder he's
our CTO um I you know encouraged him to
join me on the journey uh and and I
don't I don't think he has any regrets
around joining joining me on this
journey Well, given given where you are
today, I I have to imagine not. So, you
you all are working at at at this other
company. You come up with this idea. You
do you start working on it while you're
there or do you all leave burn the boats
behind you and say, "We're we're doing
this and we're all in on this on this
concept. We're going to go build a
company." Yeah. No, we we left. Um so,
we were working on a company full-time.
Now one of the things that happened
around that time is joining uh um a team
called NFX. Uh NFX is today it's a
series seed and series A fund. At the
time it was a fund plus an accelerator
and so we joined their accelerator
program. Um and that is actually where
Rome and I made the decision to pivot
and it was great to work with you know
James Courier and Pete Flint and Ge
Weissy in terms of figuring out what to
do next and so they were they were
awesome thought partners as well. Had
you all raised money against the initial
concept or were you bootstrapping it?
What where were you in your process?
Yeah, we were bootstrapping. Um we
didn't raise c like you know meaningful
capital until we started Incredible
Health. So what we did was you know part
of this framework is when when you have
an idea really think through the market
size um think through the competition
and then think through your unique
insights like what have you figured out
that's so that will that is so much that
is 10x at least 10x you know smarter
better faster cheaper more compliant
whatever it is than what's already out
there. Um and then after that if if it's
meeting you know the that those three
criteria market size, competition and
unique insight then go deep on the
really deep on the market research and
the customer research. Um so we we did
that with a few ideas and ultimately
decided to go with the incredible health
idea.
Um to share a bit more about our thought
process at the time you know our the
healthcare industry is uh the biggest
labor industry in the country by number
of workers. So one one in eight
Americans works in healthcare. It's also
an industry where we have tremendous uh
huge labor shortages, right? Like our
demand for healthcare as a country keeps
growing. Our population is aging. It's
putting more and more strain on the US
healthare system and we as a country
have not done a great job of increasing
the number of healthcare workers to meet
that demand. So we were very familiar
with that huge, you know, supply demand
imbalance. Um, as far as just like what
else is out there, you know, it was
primarily just job boards, which is, you
know, technology from 20 plus years ago,
um, which are very tough when there's a
when there's big shortages, you know,
because from an employer perspective,
you know, you're posting a job and
hoping all works out, which is really
tough when there's huge shortages. And
then similarly on the talent side or on
the candidate side, you know, the
healthcare workers were saying, I
applied to 10 places, I usually don't
even hear back, right? Um and so and
then and then came our unique insight,
you know. So there's a few unique things
that we did with incredible health at
where we believed it was at least 10x
better than what's already out there.
One was having employers apply to the
talent instead of the other way around.
Um so we really flipped, you know,
flipped the script, flipped it around.
Instead of waiting for healthcare
workers to apply to employers, have the
employers apply to the healthcare
workers because of the supply demand in
dynamics. We also worked on automating
the matching and automating the
screening because of where software was
at that time and still today. I mean
there's just we had the ability to do
that at scale. Um and so those are those
are some of the initial insights that we
had come we had come up with and so
ultimately decided to pursue pursue the
idea based on that. Of course we did a
little bit of customer research too. We
spoke with health system executives. We
spoke with nurses and and really you
know heard the urgency in their voice.
So, it was almost like an emotional
experience for them in terms of just the
problems that they're tackling and and
and that they're having with with with
you know, hiring in general. I imagine
that part of the advantage of the pivot
also was you went from pitching software
to thousands upon thousands of
prospective customers who were not all
that practiced in evaluating new
software systems and what have you. And
all of a sudden, you know, correct me if
I'm wrong, but you're pitching like
Kaiser. you're you're pitching huge
healthcare companies that have this
massive need for talent and we have a
talent shortage. So I was part of it
also that you saw that your sales
channels and sales cycles would be
cleaner and shorter. Was that was that
part of the insight as well? Yeah, I
mean that's that's a great thought. I
mean one key learning we that was
definitely one of our learnings and uh
you know selling in the enterprise world
uh you are working with a more
sophisticated set of buyers. Um and uh
that meant for us we really had to have
it wasn't just about having an awesome
product that works. We have to have a
amazing business case and ROI and you
know all of that had to had to be put in
place too. Yeah. So, I mean, I'm I'm
curious as you were looking at the
marketplace and well, obviously there's
LinkedIn and obviously there's Zip
Recruiter and other, you know, platforms
that do this. This is this is what they
do. They've done this for a long time.
Um, what did you see that you could do
10x better than the existing platforms
for job applicants, for recruiting, etc.
in healthcare specifically?
Yeah. So, the first was the vertical
focus on just healthcare, right? Um one
of the complaints our customers how our
customers have like the health systems
have is that um these horizontal
marketplaces uh like LinkedIn and Zip
Recruiter and so on are not necessarily
customized for healthcare. The reason
that matters is there's healthcare is a
regulated industry. Um you have to you
know the healthcare workers have
licenses and certifications and and so
on that all that all of that matters. So
that was one piece. The second piece was
just the the employers applying to the
talent study the other way around. So
it's a completely different experience
and you can as you can imagine for
healthcare workers they absolutely love
it right they create a profile they sit
back and relax they get interview
requests they get to decide which
interviews they accept or decline and it
you know we're often described by
healthcare workers as the this was the
best job search experience of my entire
career we have thousands of fivestar
reviews across Google and Facebook and
the app store with them describing about
what an amazing experience and what a
delightful experience it's been. Um the
other insight that we had was just
around the automation of of of screening
and and of matching and that's really
what brings enormous benefit to the
employers in particular as well as the
to the healthcare workers. You know for
the employers it's usually a very small
team internally that's trying to hire
like a lot of roles. Um and you know we
started with we started with nursing
we've now expanded to technicians and
technologists but you know it was
usually at that time it was you know one
recruiter would be trying to fill a
hundred roles in nursing um in a highly
competitive market and so they very much
value the fact that the talent was
pre-screened and prevetted and custom ma
and custom matched to their to their
needs. Yeah. and and the
the the one of the challenges of
building a two-sided marketplace is it's
like you can't open a nightclub and not
have patrons there. It feels really
weird to show up and be one of six
people there. So when you were when you
were building this and you were getting
at least some positive feedback on the
the demand side, right, on the on the
employer side, how did you go about
filling up the candidate pool quickly
enough so that the employers were were
able to screen through these candidates
at volume and be able to say, "Oh, no,
these are the 10 we're desperate to talk
to." Yeah. So we honestly use a lot of
the classic tactics that other two-sided
marketplaces in Silicon Valley use. Um
so first and foremost we were geograph
we ensured we made sure we were
geographically constrained. So for
example in the first two years of this
business we were only in California.
Like incredible health was only
available in the Bay Area and the LA
area. That's it for two years. Um and it
wasn't until our third year that we
started expanding to other states. Uh
the reason that mattered that mattered a
lot is to build up the supply and demand
uh at the same time in a in a cons in a
in a constrained way because we were
limited on resources at the time as
well. At the time the team is like you
know less than 10 people. I think we'd
raised a $2 million seed round but like
that was it. Um we also wanted to make
sure that our product and operations
were were good enough to drive success
for both sides of our marketplace. And
that was that was an enormous amount of
product development and operational work
that had to happen at the time. It was
wonderful working with that those early
adopter health systems then because they
were very um engaged and understanding
of what was happening and they were I I
consider them some of our development
partners like they were they were
influencing our product uh and our
operations at the time too. Will you
tell us how you landed your first
employer side partner and then how you
engaged them to help um uh evolve your
product roadmap? Yeah. So, okay, we've
now grown to over 1,500 hospitals. Um,
we work with that's a lot of hospitals.
It's a lot of hospitals in the US and
the largest, you know, we work with the
largest health systems including
Ascension and Trinity and HCA and um and
we work with many community hospitals.
We also work with many academic medical
centers like like New York Presbyterian
and NYU and Cedar Sinai and many many
others like that. So, if we if I rewind
back to the early days, I think we got
the very first health system through
cold calling. There was no we didn't
have a sales team at the time so it was
just me. Um and I was I would spend
hours each day cold calling, cold
emailing and you know got each got a
hold of someone. Uh uh I still remember
her name. Her name was Gloria. And what
was Gloria's role at HCA? Gloria is a
recruiter. God bless Gloria. Yeah. A
very experienced recruiter. And so I
sort of explained what we're we're up to
at the you know at the time there's not
we don't have a fancy deck and you know
presentation there's none of that it's
just a conversation they helped us
really improve our reporting our
analytics how to explain and and the
return on investment and the business
case so you know we just we just stayed
in really close touch with both groups
of users um we were probably in touch
with our customers you know every single
week honestly look seven years later I'm
still speaking with customers almost
every day right um I still listen to
recordings of of our team's call with
with with the healthcare workers, you
know. Um, so it one of our and the
number one value at Incredible Health
Company value we have is customer
obsession like do whatever you can to
delight your users and that's like
firmly embedded in our culture and the
way we do our work. And so we encourage,
you know, and and that's that's a value
that's required of every single team.
This isn't just for the product team.
This is for everyone, operations,
finance, everybody. Yeah. I I imagine as
a founder and CEO um uh and I'm also
imagining your your investors, your
early investors saying, "Look, this is
great. You're establishing product
market fit. you're you're growing these
geographically constrained ways so that
we're making sure that we're serving
both sides of the marketplace well. But
hey, we're two years in and we're in two
markets in California and it is a
competitive marketplace and presumably
the zip recruiters and others of the
world are seeing what you're doing and
would at least be contemplating whether
they could compete with you in
California and nationally. Were you
worried about others jumping ahead of
you in in the in the broader national
market or did you feel you had such a
competitive advantage that you could
take your time to to really get it right
in California before you expanded? Yeah,
I mean look, my my perspective on
competition is it's good it's good to be
aware of them and and and to study them
and learn that learn from them. Uh but I
don't I really don't think founders and
CEOs should be obsessing or focusing
very much on them. Um I I I think the
obsession needs to be on the customers,
not on the competition. So I want to
drill into this for a second because um
I imagine if you'd waited five years to
go beyond California, that would have
been too long, right? Because others
would have caught up and what have you.
Um and I'm curious if if you had
investors or advisers who were
encouraging you to scale fast, like blit
scale this thing. Let's go. Let's get
out there and beat the market.
How did that play out for you and and
how did you know when it was time to go
outside of California and go more
national? Yeah, it's a it's a great
question. Um, this is I'll I'll start by
saying like this is the benefit of
having really high quality investors.
Um, I work with James Walken at Obvious
Ventures who's another OG been doing the
internet thing since the late 90s. He's
a he's a great guy. He he and his wife Z
are are phenomenal people. They're
awesome. And uh you know James has been
built and James built has built like
seven companies right he had a whole
operating career before uh being c
before uh his investing career and then
also I work with Jeff Jordan and
Horowitz. So Jeff Jordan was the CEO of
Open Table. So honestly I had very good
investors who know a ton about not just
software and the internet but also about
marketplaces.
Um so uh with the benefit of their
advice right we wanted to make sure that
we the marketplace was working well in
two geographies at least before we scale
it further um specific and this was very
specific like I'm referring to our unit
economics I'm referring to our margins
per hire I'm referring to uh the volume
of hires that are happening like really
and and as well as the qualitative
feedback of of this is an amazing
experience you know from the c from from
both sides of the platform too. Um it
came to be so I never really got a ton
of pressure from investors to expand
rapidly um until we got to you know
strong stronger metrics. Once we got to
the stronger metrics then actually that
actually triggered me to raise our
series A which was another $15 million
and with that we expanded to more
states.
Um the other the other thing that um to
to be honest like thinking back to that
time it was actually our customers that
were pushing us to leave cal to expand
beyond California more than our
investors. Um you know especially with
some of the bigger health systems we
were working with. They were like this
is working great in California like when
are you coming to Texas and Nevada and
you know etc. So we had to actually tell
our customers like you know hold your
horses like we got to address a few
things and then and then we'll we'll
we'll support you. But it was a great
way to grow because we were able to grow
and expand to other states with our
customers. Yeah. And wonderful that that
you you know the demand is there before
you even show up there. Um the the model
for incredible health is interesting
because um uh only one side of this
marketplace pays if I understand it
correctly. Is that right? So h how is
how does the business model actually
work? Yeah. So okay, Incredible Health
today is now the largest software and AI
enabled career marketplace for
healthcare workers. the business model
is based on um employers paying you know
so employers are able
to benefit enormously from this from
incredible health specifically what I'm
referring to is uh we've we've achieved
a a days to hire of 20 days on average
on the platform which is compared to the
national average of 80 days for
experienced and specialized nurse hiring
is is really strong um we also drive
really strong ROI for them specifically
around cost savings so for every
hospital we work with we save them at
least $5 million a year uh because by
hiring permanent nurses faster from
Incredible Health, they're able to
reduce their temporary labor and
overtime costs. And so for so for uh for
the employers is honestly a no-brainer
like that the ROI is so strong that that
is why they pay for incredible health.
Um and so as a result we've been able to
effectively subsidize the healthcare
worker side, you know, so we we can
provide all kinds of free tools and
services to the healthcare workers. Um
and that piece has been really important
to our strategy too. For the health care
workers,
uh it's it incredible health is more
than just about finding a job. It's
about managing their career. So we
provide a whole range of free tools and
services to the healthcare workers
including uh continuing education uh and
salary estimators and a community where
they can ask each other for advice and
they get access to career coaches too
that help them with interview
preparation. I mean it's a pretty full
suite of services on the healthcare
worker side. Um that helps give them a
more delightful experience too. You have
1500 employers on the platform. Is that
right? Um and some of those are very big
organizations. Um how many how many on
the employee side? How many on the
candidate uh team member side? Yeah. So
we have over 1 million nurses on the
platform. That's a lot of nurses. It's a
lot. One in three nurses in the country
uses Incredible Health to manage their
careers.
Extraordinary. This is just in in about
seven years that you've done this. You
said that you're a big fan of five and
10 year plans. Um uh and we're in a
world where it's hard to see what's
coming 6 months from now, much less 5
years down the road. When you look out 5
years for incredible health, what do you
see? We're continuing to pursue the same
vision and mission of helping health
care professionals live better lives and
helping them find and do their best
work. were very still we continue to be
very customer obsessed uh and and and
that those that company value continues.
Um we you know the in five years we will
be in more categories uh more than just
you know nurses and techn technicians
and more than just hospitals and surgery
centers and home health. Um our goal
ultimately is to be in all aspects of
healthcare on the employer side and on
the uh healthcare worker side. And then
we will also be embracing the latest and
greatest technologies in order to
deliver our service. So um yeah a
exciting the next five years will be
very exciting. So you're focused on the
healthcare sector uh understand that you
know relentless focus uh on the
category. Um, if you were advising uh a
company that's that's trying to do
something similar in a in a completely
unrelated category, what would you say
they have to do to make this a better
experience both for the employers trying
to recruit and for the the prospective
team members they're going after? Yeah,
I mean I I think I'll answer that
question in a way that's maybe advice
for all hiring, you know. Um, so even at
Incredible Health, we have to hire for
our team as well. Um, look, there's a
whole range of best practices out there.
Um, speed is a key one. You know, moving
candidates through your process, not
ghosting them, ensuring they're clear on
what the next step is, having a really
clear process internally, like all that
really does matter and drives a really
very delightful candidate experience. I
think being very clear about what you're
actually looking for and defining your
role accurately is is is important as
well in terms of what's the what are the
must-haves versus the nice to haves. We
ran into this issue a lot in healthcare
and we run into in tech as well where um
you know hiring managers and leaders can
put all kinds of criteria and which can
just kill a pipeline or a funnel. Um and
and we need to really ask ourselves some
tough questions like do we really need
all of all of this criteria uh to get
the right person. Um and then uh another
one is just uh you know also related to
process is to just have very clear
timelines as well. You know um you know
there should be the the amount of time
to complete a phone screen to complete a
hiring manager interview to get an offer
out. They should be relatively short
timelines and so candidates can get
through within days um not not weeks or
months. Um so those are all just you
know tips that we've learned. Um you're
you're is your dad still with us? He is.
Yeah. And he's a doctor.
Um is he proud of of the work you're
doing? How how does h how is it when you
talk to him about the work that you're
doing as a as a health care professional
who focused presumably on on individual
patients? Seeing your impact on an
entire nation's health care system. Um
what's that like for him? Yeah, I mean
both honestly both my parents are are
proud of of what we've done. Um I I
think that in the early days they were
uh a little skeptical like is this a
real thing? Like is this you're not
working a normal job, you know, like
there was a little definitely a little
bit of skepticism in the first few
years. But once we really got going and
certainly once the press started, you
know, paying attention, that's when they
were like, "Oh, okay. This is this is
real. This is actually happening. You're
a doctor. What are you doing? You're
And here." Yeah. My dad does not talk to
me about doing an anesthesiology
residency anymore.
And even with the the million nurses you
have on the platform um and this you
know radically better way of going
through um a job search process on both
sides. We have a real nursing shortage
in this country. Um we have a real
healthare worker shortage in this
country. um what do you see as some of
the solutions for that broadly and and
what can Incredible Health do to to help
there aside from creating a great
experience in the job search process?
Yeah, for uh for healthcare workers,
let's let's first just examine the the
bottl necks like what is stopping us
from increasing the number of healthcare
workers in this country.
uh uh one one area is that it's
important to point out that there
there's actually quite a lot of demand
from Americans to get into nursing and
some of these other professions. For
example, for nursing schools, there's
weight lists of tens of thousands of
Americans who want to get in, but they
can't get in. So, we have a really big
bottleneck at the school level and and
they can't get in because there just
aren't enough slots. We we haven't we
haven't made the system efficient enough
for the training for for us to take the
number of people who want the training.
Yeah. So the number of ner the I'm
referring to nursing schools and
technician schools. Uh there's not
enough faculty to deliver to to to
teach. There's also not enough schools
period. Uh there's not enough slots
openings to take on to train more. Uh
and so that that's a huge bottleneck.
Another bottleneck that's happening is
right after school. Uh because school is
just the beginning. you know, you
actually have to end up getting trained
and getting specialized and so on. And
